010package imagingbook.common.color.colorspace;
011
012import static imagingbook.common.math.Matrix.multiply;
013
014/**
015 * <p>
016 * This class represents a linear chromatic adaptation transform,
017 * mapping XYZ color coordinates from a source white (reference) point
018 * to a target white point. 
019 * Both white points are passed to the constructor.
020 * The actual color mapping is done by method {@link #applyTo(float[])}.
021 * The underlying linear transformation is specified by matrix 'Mcat',
022 * which may be retrieved by {@link #getMcat()}).
023 * See the Section 14.6 of [1] for additional details and examples.
024 * </p>
025 * <p>
026 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing - An Algorithmic Approach</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
027 * </p>
028 */
029public class BradfordAdaptation implements ChromaticAdaptation {
030        
031        // CAT transform matrices (forward and inverse)
032        private static double[][] Mfwd = {
033            { 0.8951,  0.2664, -0.1614},
034            {-0.7502,  1.7135,  0.0367},
035            { 0.0389, -0.0685,  1.0296}};
036            
037        private static double[][] Minv = {      
038                { 0.9869929055, -0.1470542564, 0.1599626517}, 
039                { 0.4323052697,  0.5183602715, 0.0492912282},
040                {-0.0085286646,  0.0400428217, 0.9684866958}};
041        
042//      private static double[][] Minv = Matrix.inverse(Mfwd);
043        
044        //      the complete color adaptation transformation matrix
045        private final double[][] Mcat;
046        
047        /**
048         * Constructor accepting two white points (XYZ-coordinates).
049         * @param W1 source white point
050         * @param W2 target white point
051         */
052        public BradfordAdaptation(double[] W1, double[] W2) {
053                double[] rgb1 = multiply(Mfwd, W1);
054                double[] rgb2 = multiply(Mfwd, W2);
055                double[][] Mrgb = rgbMatrix(rgb1, rgb2);
056                Mcat = multiply(Minv, multiply(Mrgb, Mfwd));
057        }
058        
059        /**
060         * Constructor accepting two {@link Illuminant} instances for
061         * specifying the source and target white points.
062         * @param illum1 source illuminant
063         * @param illum2 target illuminant
064         */
065        public BradfordAdaptation(Illuminant illum1, Illuminant illum2) {
066                this(illum1.getXYZ(), illum2.getXYZ());
067        }
068        
069        // transformation of color coordinates
070        @Override
071        public float[] applyTo(float[] XYZ1) {
072                // XYZ2 = Mcat . XYZ1
073                float[] XYZ2 = new float[3];
074                for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
075                        XYZ2[i] = (float) (Mcat[i][0] * XYZ1[0] + Mcat[i][1] * XYZ1[1] + Mcat[i][2] * XYZ1[2]);
076                }
077                return XYZ2;
078        }
079        
080        /**
081         * Returns the color adaptation transformation matrix (Mcat).
082         * @return the color adaptation transformation matrix
083         */
084        public double[][] getMcat() {
085                return this.Mcat;
086        }
087        
088
089        // Creates a diagonal matrix with the ratios of the rgb components
090        // obtained by transforming the two white points
091        // TODO: no deed to create a matrix!!
092        private double[][] rgbMatrix(double[] rgb1, double[] rgb2) {
093                if (rgb1.length != rgb2.length)
094                        throw new IllegalArgumentException();
095                int n = rgb1.length;
096                double[][] Madapt = new double[n][n];
097                for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
098                        Madapt[i][i] = rgb2[i] / rgb1[i];
099                }
100                return Madapt;
101        }
102        
103        // ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
104        
105//      public static void main(String[] args) {
106//

108//              
109//              System.out.println("Mcat = \n" + Matrix.toString(adapt.getMcat()));
110//              System.out.println();
111//              
112//              
113//              PrintPrecision.set(4);
114//              ColorSpace cs = new sRgb65ColorSpace();
115//              float[] red = {1, 0, 0};
116//              float[] grn = {0, 1, 0};
117//              float[] blu = {0, 0, 1};
118//              
119//              float[] rgb1 = blu;
120//              
121//              System.out.println("rgb1 = " + Matrix.toString(rgb1));
122//              float[] XYZ65 = cs.toCIEXYZ(rgb1);
123//              System.out.println("XYZ65 = " + Matrix.toString(XYZ65));
124//              
125//              float[] xy65 = CieUtil.xyzToxy(XYZ65);
126//              System.out.println("xy65 = " + Matrix.toString(xy65));
127//              
128//              float[] XYZ50 = adapt.applyTo(XYZ65);
129//              System.out.println("XYZ50 = " + Matrix.toString(XYZ50));
130//              
131//              float[] xy50 = CieUtil.xyzToxy(XYZ50);
132//              System.out.println("xy50 = " + Matrix.toString(xy50));
133//              
134//              float[] rgb2 = cs.fromCIEXYZ(XYZ65);
135//              System.out.println("rgb2 = " + Matrix.toString(rgb2));
136//              
137//      }
138//      
139        
140}
